Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Investigating the Composition, Behavior, and Environmental Fate of Emerging Unconventional Oils from North America: Bakken Crude Oils and Canadian Diluted Bitumens

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1547132
Reddy

This study will investigate the composition, behavior, and environmental fate of crude oils and bitumens in order to produce a robust baseline data set desperately needed by scientists, policy makers, and spill responders. The production and transport of these two emerging unconventional petroleum products has been hailed as the path to North American energy independence, and their production continues to expand at a dramatic pace.

The lack of data available in the peer-reviewed literature has hindered a robust understanding of the risks associated with environmental discharge of these products. These emerging unconventional products have already been analyzed for their chemical and physical properties and these data will be used along with some additional analyses to understand their environmental fate and transport. The results of this research will extend beyond publications and presentations and be used to actively engage critical stakeholders. This effort will support a postdoctoral scientist, inform industry and government officials, and provide accessible information to the media, policy makers, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs). By giving the PIs cause to interact outside their peer group, this research will also allow them to learn about the interests and needs of others and improve bidirectional communication between academia and other stakeholders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Christopher Reddy (Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution) and Professor Robert Swarthout (Appalachian State University) investigated the chemical composition/properties of crude oil from the Bakken oil fields of North Dakota and diluted bitumen, or "dilbit," from the Canadian tar sands. 

 

They measured the concentration of many different chemicals found in these products. The differences between the Bakken crude oils and dilbits were so striking that Reddy, Swarthout, and other co-authors reported on them in a book chapter in the Standard Handbook of Oil Spill Forensics. They also examined the density and viscosity, which are critical in determining how they will act when spilled in water.

 

Reddy and Swarthout also investigated the environmental fate of oil in the first dilbit spill to occur in the United States. In 2010, 843,000 gallons of dilbit leaked from a ruptured pipeline into the Kalamazoo River in Michigan making it the largest inland oil spill in United States history. Much of this oil was submerged over time and cleanup of the bottom of the river is still ongoing in 2016 and has cost billions of dollars. Along with collaborators at the Michigan State University, Reddy and Swarthout collected and analyzed samples of bark from trees that were coated with oil during the spill five years prior to collection. Concentrations of chemicals in these oiled bark samples were nearly identical to the original oil with only a five-percent loss of the oil over five years. They also used a physical-chemical model to show that the majority of this loss was caused by evaporation of the oil and not by the oil dissolving into the river water. Their work demonstrated just how different dilbit spills are from spills of light sweet crude oil that have been extensively studied since the Deepwater Horizon disaster. The results of this work were presented at the American Geophysical Union's Ocean Sciences Meeting in 2016 and will form the foundation of future work to address how spilled dilbit will behave in other environments like the open ocean and coastal areas.

 

Reddy and Swarthout's work has been shared with researchers, responders, and regulators at the EPA and US Coast Guard/NOAA, the government organizations responsible for responding to oil spills on land and in coastal waters, respectively. Establishing these working relationships between academic scientists and government agencies is crucial for building our capacity to safely and responsibly develop emerging fossil fuel resources and to be able to respond effectively when spills do occur.
